data_findings.finding: This is a 2D packing optimization problem: pack Christmas tree shapes (15-vertex polygons) into smallest square bounding box for N=1 to 200 trees. Score = sum(side^2/N) for all N. Lower is better. Target: 68.931058
Key optimizer: bbox3 binary - runs with -n (iterations) and -r (parameter). Used by top kernels. Typical params: -n 1000-10000, -r 4-256
fix_direction optimization: Rotates entire configuration to minimize bounding box using scipy.optimize.minimize_scalar on convex hull. Multiple passes improve results.
Overlap repair: When bbox3 creates overlaps, replace those N configurations with known good ones from donor file
Santa Claude kernel: C++ optimizer with simulated annealing, local search, compaction, squeeze, swap moves, multi-start. Also has backward propagation (removing trees from N to improve N-1 configs)
2D polygon packing optimization techniques: simulated annealing, local search, branch-and-bound, shelf packing, meta-CSP with pairwise relationships, squeeze/compaction operations, genetic algorithms

web_research.query: What are the best algorithms for 2D polygon packing optimization to minimize bounding box?
web_research.finding:
Two‑dimensional polygon packing that seeks the smallest enclosing rectangle (the bounding box) is usually tackled with either **exact branch‑and‑bound methods** for small‑to‑moderate instances or **polynomial‑time approximation/shelf‑packing heuristics** for larger, more complex sets of polygons.

*Exact approaches.*  The classic state‑of‑the‑art exact solvers treat the problem as an **absolute‑placement** or **perfect‑packing** search.  Korf’s anytime branch‑and‑bound algorithm enumerates x‑coordinates first, then branches on feasible y‑positions while using a lower‑bound derived from a one‑dimensional bin‑packing relaxation and dominance pruning to cut large parts of the search tree ([arxiv.org](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2402.07666)).  Huang & Korf later refined this idea with a “perfect‑packing” transformation that adds dummy rectangles so that every partial solution has no empty space, dramatically speeding up the search and extending optimal solutions for the consecutive‑square benchm
